statement:
Let $B_k$ denote the $k$th Bernoulli number:
$$B_0=1,\quad B_1=-\frac{1}{2},\quad B_2=\frac{1}{6},\quad B_3=0,\quad B_4=-\frac{1}{30},\ldots$$
In fact, $B_k=0$ for all odd $k\geq 3$, so we will only consider $B_k$
for even $k$. The following is a well-known congruence, due to Thomas
Clausen and Karl von Staudt.

For an even integer $k\geq 2$,

$$B_k \equiv -\sum_{p \text{ prime},\ (p-1)|k} \frac{1}{p} \mod {\mathbb{Z}}$$
where the sum is over all primes $p$ such that $(p-1)$ divides $k$. In
other words, there exists an integer $n_k$ such that
$$B_k=n_k -\sum_{p \text{ prime},\ (p-1)|k} \frac{1}{p}.$$

For example:
$$B_2=\frac{1}{6}=1-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}, \quad B_4=-\frac{1}{30}=1-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{5}.$$
Sometimes the theorem is stated in this alternative form:

For an even integer $k\geq 2$ and any prime $p$ the product $pB_k$ is
$p$-integral, that is, $pB_k$ is a rational number $t/s$ (in lowest
terms) such that $p$ does not divide $s$. Moreover:
$$pB_k \equiv \begin{cases}
-1 \mod p, \text{ if $(p-1)$ divides $k$;}\\
0 \mod p, \text{ if $(p-1)$ does not divide $k$}.
\end{cases}$$
names: congruence of Clausen and von Staudt
